The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

[Your Hospital Letterhead]

Date: 2024-02-14

To Whom It May Concern,

Re: Discharge Summary for ___ [Patient's Name]

Patient Information:
Age: 70
Gender: Male
Admission Date: 2024-02-10
Discharge Date: 2024-02-14

We are writing to provide a summary of the hospital stay for ___ [Patient's Name] who was admitted to our facility on February 10, 2024.

Admission Details:
The patient presented with the primary symptoms of cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon further evaluation, the diagnosis of lobar pneumonia of unspecified organism was established, corresponding to diagnosis code J18.1.

Medical Course During Hospitalization:
Upon admission, an empirical antibiotic therapy was initiated with Amoxicillin IV, administrated at a dose of 500 mg every 8 hours. Supportive care with Paracetamol was provided as required. Initial physical examination indicated a temperature of 38.5°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92%.

A Chest X-Ray performed on the day of admission revealed consolidation in the left lower lobe, consistent with the diagnosis of pneumonia. The patient's C-reactive protein (CRP) was found to be elevated at 60 mg/L initially, and white blood cell (WBC) count was recorded at 12 x10^9/L.

By February 11, the patient's condition showed signs of improvement, with a reduction in CRP levels to 50 mg/L and WBC count to 11 x10^9/L. The Amoxicillin IV dose was adjusted to 250 mg daily, and Atorvastatin PO at 20 mg nightly was initiated. Observations recorded included a temperature of 37.8°C and stable oxygen saturation at 94%.

Over the subsequent days, the patient demonstrated further clinical improvement. On February 12, the patient’s temperature normalized to 37°C, and CRP and WBC levels reduced appropriately to 35 mg/L and 9 x10^9/L, respectively. Oxygen saturation improved to 96%, allowing the medical team to plan the transition to oral antibiotics.

Discharge Planning:
By February 13, the patient continued to exhibit recovery, with CRP and WBC levels continuing to trend downwards. The patient was deemed ready for discharge planning, with oral Amoxicillin commenced at a daily dose of 250 mg.

Discharge Condition:
Upon discharge on February 14, 2024, the patient's condition was stable, with vital signs within normal ranges: temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, blood pressure of 118/74 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 14 breaths/min with an oxygen saturation of 98%.

Recommendations and Follow-Up:
The patient is advised to continue oral Amoxicillin for a total of 5 days post-discharge. It is recommended that the patient attends a follow-up appointment in the outpatient clinic in two weeks for reassessment.

We are grateful for the opportunity to have cared for ___ [Patient's Name] and are pleased with the positive outcome of treatment. Should there be any queries or need for further information, please do not hesitate to contact our office.

Yours sincerely,

[Your Name]
[Your Position]
[Your Contact Information] 

cc: ___ [Primary Care Physician’s Name]
